title: Has Russia under Putin become a more effective challenger to the US than the Soviet Union ever was? - Quora
tags: Russia and the United States of America

response.answer_text: In terms of Output-to-Input Ratio, Russia under Putin is more effective in challenging the West than the USSR was. Punching far above the weight Unlike the USSR, Russian Federation is dwarfed by the US militarily, economically and ideologically. However, President Putin is able to punch far above his weight. Since 2016 he’s been an official kingmaker in American politics, admired by as diverse players as leftists, hard Evangelicals, right libertarians and white supremacists. He has been pushing America from their traditional areas of influence in the Middle East, and even gaining ground among NATO members like Turkey and Hungary. His authoritarian model of “sovereign democracy” is respected by President Trump who trusts him more than his own secret services. Despite the glaring inequality perpetuated by his state-oligarchical system, Marxists and other leftists around the globe prefer Russia over America as the leading challenger to the dark forces of liberal democracy. Different game This has been achieved thanks to a fundamental choice made by Putin during his second presidential term about 15 years ago. Instead of frontal confrontation with the West, like the USSR, he chose the way of disruptive power projection. This is typically used by guerrilla forces around the world. This is the only way guerrilla can resist a military superior enemy: constant harassment, disruption of the logistics and trickles of attrition. Another example of effective disruptive power is the German submarine warfare during WW2. Playing for strength From the military point of view, disruptive power projection is a dead end because it doesn’t have a distinct objective. The course of the war is still decided by the enemy, and it’s only the degree of the enemy’s exhaustion that may—or may not—tip its outcome. However, from the point of view of secret operatives, it’s a much smarter way of warfare. They like the absence of well-defined front lines, the possibility to scale it up or down at will, the variety of non-lethal tools it offers, and no distinction between combatants and civilians. This is a game President Putin knows and likes. And it shows.  Below, a picture often posted by Putin-critical radical nationalists in Russia. It shows the directors on the board of our state-owned oil company Rosneft. Along with Gazprom, Rosneft is the falgship of our extractive economy, the bottomless source of President Putin’s economic muscle. The head of the board is German, and Westerners are almost outnumbering Russians, with four American heavyweights among them. The radical nationalists see that as a proof that Putin is just another country manager appointed by the global oligarchical elite. The loyalists, on the contrary, point this out as another proof that President Putin, once again, has outfoxed everyone. Any way, this shows the global leverage that Russia now possesses, totally unthinkable under Soviet rule.

Not by a long shot. The Russia of the Cold War controlled half of Europe. The USSR alone had a vast population and vast resources. The Soviets and their captive nations had a larger if less capable military than the west, and the outcome of a war in Europe was not at all assured:  Furthermore, after the humiliation of the Cuban Missile Crisis, Russia began a buildup of strategic nuclear weapons that soon led it to achieve parity with the US, and even superiority. Add to that the fact that the Soviet policy was one of expansion through insurgency, while our policy was one of containment. Simple math tells us that that led to an expanding Soviet sphere of influence. Not until the Soviet expulsion from Afghanistan was the process reversed. For more than two decades, we thought that the USSR might triumph, that we might lose a war, that the entire world might become Communist. But above all, we were afraid of a nuclear war that would destroy us all. In two cases, only the wisdom of a single man separated the world from nuclear annihilation. Comparing that to today’s Russia is like comparing pneumonia to a sneeze. Then, it was an existential threat; today, it is an inmate who thinks he’s Napoleon. Putin does everything he can to hurt the democratic world, just as the Soviet government did — but he’s like a mosquito biting an elephant, rather than another elephant. The real shame here is that Russia, the country that put the first man into space, is today a backwards petrostate. With its vast natural resources and educated population it could be a prosperous, respected, influential nation. But to do that, it would have to stop trying to be the world’s bogeyman, something that has brought it only isolation and economic sanctions, and rid itself instead of its authoritarian kleptocractic government.

no, not even close. Soviet Union was equal in terms of its influence on the world to the US. That is why it was a serious business to study what Soviets think and plan in the US. Currently that area is filled with clueless clowns who thinks they can send warships to the sea of azov (max depth 15m) or kill Russian personnel in Syria with impunity However, the more fundamental reason is that Putin does not seek confrontation but co-existence. So, Russia does not really challenge the US strategically or more importantly ideologically. It simply seeks to protect its own turf and its traditional sphere of influence. That was the deal he offered on several occasions until 2007 Munich speech. I think that is the point he concluded that seeking an agreement was futile and the clash is result of US not accepting the new reality that Russia is no more the dysfunctional state under Yeltsin and they still seek to bring down Russia under its fold. Otherwise Putin would have been more than happy to cooperate, in my view also for plundering the rest of the world. He just don’t want to see Russia to be as another vassal state and be on the table but not on the menu.

I hope so because we are doing a different kind of challenge. Unlike the USSR, modern Russia doesn’t really have a broad problem with American Capitalism, American values. American movies, etc. We just have a very specific problem with the American idea that the USA can and should run the whole world, kill anyone who opposes it, destroy foreign economies and countries at will, etc. We are not challenging American essence, we are challenging a particular policy. And we see that a lot of people across the world, even in the United States, don’t like that policy too. Building a Socialist world was an unrealistic Utopian dream. Making America step back a bit is much more realistic. And our case for it is a lot more relatable for our supporters, actual and potential.

No. The Soviet Union was scary-scary. It surprised the world, and the US, first with Sputnik, then with Gagarin, next with Khrushchev speeches, which, as one American told me, “scared sh*t out of Americans”. But you don’t watch videos like “Duck and cover” anymore, do you? I read a lot of American sci-fi books, translated, and a few authors saw future world divided between the West block and the Communist block, or destroyed in all-out war of blocks. It changed a lot since then, you even may ask me if it really was like that. Contemporary Russia does not impress people in the US that much. All the blah-blah-blah about Russian “threats to democracy” are more media noise, trying to divert attention from the problems inside the US.

Do you mean his “ tough guy, strong leader “ PR propoganda ? How's that still selling to the home crowd fans ? How's that flat economy treating the Russian citizens ? How about those pensioners ? Putin's short several satellite states, has earned sanctions from 40 nations for invading Crimea, and many former CCCP client states want nothing to do with Putin's Russia. An economy a fraction that of the US, and crappy infrastructure outside 2 major cities. Russia's Superpower days died 29 years ago. Challenging the US in what ? Hard military power, softpower influence ? Russia is # 2 to China in the East, and fading fast. Let Russians think what they want. Bombast and propoganda about weapons is a pretty lame “ challenge “.

Russia, under Putin, has the same problems it has had for centuries. It has a lot of natural resources, with poor transportation of those assets to ports. Lots of fertile land which is five degrees too cold for productivity. No good ocean access. Limited access from the Black Sea past Turkey. St. Petersburg up north and frozen too much. And Vladivostok at the end of a very long railroad. Stalin wrecked things by making the countries on the west resent the existence of its old rulers. Putin has to get the NorthWest Passage usable despite US and Canadian maritime claims. And the Danish claim as well. Putin has a lot of fences to mend, indeed.

Not by a long shot. The Soviet Union was an existential threat. Its armies were sitting, ready to attack, in the middle of Europe. Their nuclear missiles were pointed at the United States and other Western nations, a trigger away from launch. They financed groups and nations hostile to the United States and its allies, some actually fighting American troops (Vietnam, Korea). Not only that, but it fielded an ideology with a power of its own, which was believed in by millions of people around the world. Putin’s Russia is at worst a nuisance. It has no power projection, and the only places it intervenes are the ones where the United States have decided not to get involved in. Its economy is the size of a medium-sized country, and most of its wealth is stored abroad. It’s a kleptocracy, where the leadership essentially steals the country’s resources for itself. So, no comparison.

No. The Soviet Union had over twice the population, was actually growing faster even its sclerotic last decade than modern Russia, had a higher birth rate, and was a far greater military power. That said, US and European policymakers haughtily dismissing Russian capabilities in 2014 showed how little they knew, and their complete contempt for Russia. But Russia is by no means a strong country or anywhere near matching the power of the United States. That country is China.
